The blueberry flavor isnt fake tasting at all, and it complements the beer rather than overtaking it.  Bravo.  Another for my 2004 Hall-of-Fame list.

deep black, small brown head.  interesting aroma of coffee and blueberries, plenty of roast evident too.  just like the description, surprisingly light palate, but very smooth with lots of roastiness present.  very dry, not particularly sweet but still probably good with dessert. less blueberry in the taste than in the nose, but still an interesting experiment nonetheless!

A much better example of blueberries in beer than other blueberry beers I have tried.  The bold sweet fruitiness of the blueberries nicely complements the hearty, coffee, dry finish of the stout.  A delightful mouthful.

WOW, now this is a sexy beer, its been a while since Ive seen a head that dark, aroma of blueberries permiates the room with a subtle hint of coffee.  I purchased this out of curiosity, knowing all to well my tendancy to not appreciate these fruit themed dark brews, subconsciously fearing the tart finish that at this point I felt was unavoidable with the style, but to my surprise... the blueberry flavor is much less represented in the flavor than it is in the aroma and it seems to linger on the palate minutes after a sip but is masked by roasty notes of coffee, slightly smokey flavor, dry finish, this may very well be my favorite fruit stout to date.

a gift from Mike (BBB63) - thanks!  Black bodied - poured with a huge dark cocoa brown head that almost overflowed then slowly settled.  Sweet and roasty aroma.  Taste is malty licorice, chewy coffee raisons, and very subtle fruit - the blueberry, I assume.  Mildy hoppy finish and continuing fruityness.  More blueberry at the end.

Eight Ball black with a dark brown laquer covering; a waffer thin, firmly thick dark brown head appears, skims out to a thin collar; slow dripping ink blots and strings of lacing. 

Nice aroma here, tantalizing black licorice, dark chocolate, blackened burnt raisins, roasted coffee, black pepper, and some anise and corriander notes. Im not getting alot of blueberry, but whats there is very earthy, dark and fresh, like they threw in the whole blueberry bush, twigs, leaves, and all. Nothing fake, or so I hope. It reminds me of a subdued Bells Expedition mixed with the Harry Magills. And thats a good thing.

Taste is nice, smooth lusious front thats relatively creamy and mild with roasty tones, dark and bittersweet chocolate sweeps in dotted with spices, touches of the blueberry, then goes into a complexing little finish of drying where oaty sweetness, chocolatey dryness, nudges of coffee, and black malt roast; and way late is a return of blueberry in a very intricate earthy juicyness covered in some of the roasty drying qualities. Quite an interesting and complex brew.

Feel is close to full throughout, smooth and creamy front, soothing, warming in its spices, cooling with its oaty sweetness and blueberry fruityness. Finish is where its at, finespun and layered in dryness with great combinations of roasty stuff, sweet oats and chocolate.

This was an attractively alluring stout to behold, Yum!

Very dark with a small tan head. The nose is a nice mix of malt and blueberry. The taste is interesting, starting with the roasted coffee stout taste and slipping to a floral finish of blueberry. Im a little mixed on this one... Its almost as if it would be a good stout without the blueberry, but then again the blueberries add something I cant decide if I fully like.

Pretty beer. Pitch black with a dark tan head that doesnt fade immediately, but doesnt last. The bluebeery aroma is nice and is the first thing you notice. Under that is a bit of hop and chocolate. The malts take dominance in the flavor with chocolate laying down the foundation of the flavor with toast and a little char filling in the cracks. The blueberry is there in the flavor, but not so strongly.

On tap at the brewery. Poured a small sized tan head that contained fine sized bubbles that mostly dissipated. The hue was black with an opaque body. The aroma was lightly hoppy and blueberry. The taste was sweet, malty and coffee and raspberry. The mouthfeel was smooth and this was a medium bodied beer with sparse lacing.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a medium sized head pf dark brown colored finely sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body was opaque and dark black colored with no carbonation visible due to the opaqueness.  The aroma was mildly malted with blueberry notes.  The mouth feel was initially smooth with a lingering blueberry licorice finish.  The flavor was of blueberries and dark malts.

As has been said, pitch black. Opaque, hugely bottle conditioned, AND a large deep rich yellow-tan head.  Smells of blueberry rinds, not sweet at all, more like vegetables, or spices.  Immediately, flavor reminds me of ginger. . .what is going on?? Is this just extremely dry blueberry extract?? How is this stuff this dry?  Tastes very similar to 2004 Anchor OSA, though less spicey and a bit thinner.  Coffee rinds at the start, and a hazlenut finish with some light blueberry.  Mouthfeel is just plain light, some stickiness on the finish, from the barley, but nowhere near what a stout should be.  If they are going to call this a stout, make it a stout, not a dark colored blueberry ale.

Black, pitch black - great looking light brown head - what a stout should look like.  Light blueberry at the front of the nose, roasty with hints of coffee.  Fruity and fresh smelling.  The body is nicely fruity with delectable coffee notes.  Very little blueberry in this thing, roasty with a light palate.  A very nice base stout - doesn't really need the blueberry, it's barely detectable anyway.  Not up to the standard set by other fruit stouts like Bell's Cherry Stout, but a good stout nonetheless.

The beer poured smoothly and produced a fast fading head with minimal lace. The beer is jet black with a dark brown head. The nose is minty and the aroma is like green cardamom, not what I was expecting. The palate is also full of cardamom flavors. The beer underneath is very roasty, with predominate flavors of black coffee. This is a strange brew; the blueberry is nowhere to be found.

Pours a rich oily black with a thin light brown head.  Upon opening the bottle I can smell the blueberries.  Nose is a complex mixture of sweet blueberry and roasted chocolate malt.  The blueberry flavor is very subtle in the body, contributing a light tartness up front and slowly fading, covered by the roasted malt flavor.  Finishes dry and roasty with some lingering dark chocolate.  A novel idea and done pretty well, but as Slikwily said, it could use a little more blueberry flavor.  Nonetheless, very drinkable and enjoyable.  Thanks bbb63!

First whiff off the bottle is pure blueberry,pours a nice coal black color with a small light black head.Malty sweet aroma with a slight coffee and dark chocolate tone with the blueberry coming on strong.The flavor is a bit disappointing,High on the coffee and dark chocolate,malt as well,but the Blueberry kind of struggles to make it self known.The after taste is coffee and chocolate with a nice bitterness to it.This is a good brew for trying but i guess for my taste i would have liked a bit more blueberry.

I appear to be in disagreement with the consensus on this stout.  I found the combination of blueberries and stout flavors awkward and ultimately unsatisfying.  Poured in typical Dark Horse fashion: thick like molasses, with a brown head (yes, a brown head; this is how dark their stouts are!).  Aroma had some roasted notes but reminded me otherwise of Smuckers Blueberry Syrup.  Some licorice in the body with roasted notes and a hint of smokiness, enveloped in tart blueberry notes.  The aroma suggested blueberries would dominate the flavor, but I found otherwise.  Still, the blueberry notes muted the typical roastiness, creating a beer that was thick but not bursting with flavor by any means.  Also some roasted vegetable "off" flavors.  I'll stick with the delectable "Too" Cream Stout.

Absolutely beautiful as far as a stout is concerned. You cannot see light through this beer like most stouts. The head is a foamy bubbly tan, very deep tan and very nice to look at. Smells of malt, bitter chocolate, and the faintest hint of blueberries. Tastes quite nice actually, a roasted nut sort of flavor in the finish but a stout flavor at first. The blueberry flavor really is an accent. There is an annoying metallic flavor that interferes overall but the beer is quite nice. Coffee and chocolate.

Poured a deep dark brown with a large brown head. aroma was of roasted malt and blueberries. Taste was roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and subtle hints of blueberry. mouthfeel is light and slightly creamy. The combination of stout and blueberries easily could have been a disaster, but this beer pulls it off fairly well.

Dark brown color with a large milk chocolate uneven creamy head.  Crisp rain fresh aroma with more of the blueberry skin aroma.  Blueberries are noticable in the taste, slighltly tart, carbonated.  I could not detect much if any traditional stout characteristics: coffee, chocolate.  This beer became tiresome after 3/4 of the glass.

Chunky, eruptive bronze foam.  Impenetrable black liquid.  Lively, fresh, earthy aroma of freshly mashed blueberries, herbs,  ginger, perfume, and wood.  Hints of leaf, port, and black malts.  Blueberries add a floral touch.  Airy and phenolic.  A thin mouthfeel lies beneath the fluffy carbonation and tries to turn creamy.  Initial note of acidity with charcoal, leather, grass, and meaty molasses flavors.  Touch of vanilla, prunes, and bakers chocolate.  Burnt malt overload.  Lovely finishing notes of toffee, coconut, and espresso.  This sample was slightly metallic and oxidized, but the fresh blueberry notes and rich, Imperialesque burnt malt flavors were exquisite.  Cheers, Prof!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 23, 2004 Rerate: This last batch seems to have a stronger burnt malt, coffee, and acidic taste that before and is slightly less balanced. Again, the blueberry flavors need to be more present in the taste. I still like it and only a drop of .2 overall.--Orignal review--

Wow, DON'T be afraid of this dark. Opaque black with a huge tan head and medium-bodied. Blueberries on to the forefront but the stout characteristics are detectable (roasted malt, chocolate, coffee). The flavor however is much less aggressive. The blueberry is in the background here as the stout flavors dominate. The taste lasts on the palate. Since I like stouts and fruit beers, I found this an great combination.  I agree with last post, Marc, that this is closer to a stout than fruit beer.

Cool blueberry, vanilla, a little chocolate, and boo berry cereal.  Black as coal and a burnt sieana head.  Light mouth feel and more carbonation than extected, fortuanatly the carbonation died down at mid glass giveing way to a pleasant slightly dry bitter charactor.  Coffee, chocolate, blueberry, and ambient fruitieness came together in an amazingly effective way. Finishes chewy and roasty with a wallop of chocolate, coffee, molases and only the faintest traces of blueberry.  I'd concider this more of a stout than a fruit beer.  I've got a friend in psychprof, and he's got a friend in me.

Again, stouts aren"t a style I would normally enjoy.  This one poured dark and syrupy, with a definate smell of the blueberries.  First sip brought a suprisingly good taste, the swallow down provided an aftertaste of raw unsweetened blueberries.  Has no problem finishing this stout and would like to thank again psychprof for trading with me.

As all good stouts the beer is black as night.  Very carbonated, had a hard time pouring the beer without creating a volcano of head.  The blueberry gives a very strong aroma.  It seems that the blueberry is more powerful in the scent than the taste.  Good roasty flavor that really doesn"t give a lot of blueberry until the end.  I think a slightly sweeter stout would do very well with the blueberry flavor as well.

Based on the previous ratings it looks like psychprof has been sending this one around the country. Im glad he let me in on the fun. The smell of freshly baked muffins permeated the room upon opening the bottle. While the beer certainly had a nice blueberry flavor, I was glad that it didnt dominate the beer. It had a nice roasty, rich flavor with the blueberry striking at the finish. Very enjoyable.

I am a Marylander and one of the Old Line States biggest embarassments is Oxford Raspberry Wheat.  Being a Maryland patriot, I hate beers that advertise fruit in the name.  That feeling has come to an end.  Psych Prof, a prophet really, has provided me with this blueberry elixir that frankly boggles my scrotum.  Unlike many other reviewers, I encounter almost no head.  There is little carbonation to get in the way of this complex, nearly imperial, stout.  Completely amazing.  Imagine Storm King and blueberries.  Sound weird?  It is.

Fooled by the label.Was expecting a day at the races with Darkhorse but actually found myself to be the star of a rodeo.The stout proved to be much more of an  untamed,strong,swirling,wild black stallion than a smiling,galopping,harmless little poney.Once let loose,you better hold on tight cause youre in for quite a ride.Open the gates.Inky-black mane,excessive,over-the-top and overwhelming deeply roasted malt teaming up with turkish coffee and darkberries up in the air.Powerful,mouth-coating earthy ground coffee,thick molasses and a nice underlined blueberry fruitiness all leading to a fairly astringent finish.Thats it.You lose your balance.youre down to the ground.Body bruised,face full of dirt.You feel like a boxer after a Mike Tyson punch.F1 racer hitting the wall at full speed.You get back on your feet,limping, yet wanting more of that stuff.But PsychProf,a nice man who drove to the ranch and provided for the ride is 700 miles away from you which is quite a ride again.Thats too bad.I feel terrible now.

I love stout and I love blueberries so right away I like the idea of this beer.  pours black with a noisy tan head that quickly disappears.  the aroma is faintly of blueberry and more of roasty stoutness.  sadly so is the flavour, with the blueberry really only coming in at the end.  still quite a tasty beer, Id just like a little more fruit..

Im glad that I took a chance on a brewery a couple hours from my house that I had never heard of.  The head is impressive.  I HATE head on beers, Ive never understood them or tasted one that made me smile.  This one was out of control... about 1 inch of beer and six inches of head shot up immediately and then immediately receded.  Ive never liked flavored stouts either, but if youd have mixed a decent stout with Boo Berry cereal, you would end up with this.  The stout part of it is fine, but nothing too out of the ordinary.  The blend between the two of them is near flawless.  Try this if you like flavored stouts or just remember sitting around in your underoos spilling booberry cereal on yourself as you tried to watch Saturday morning cartoons before you went out to play guns with your friends before kids ever thought about using guns at school because their parents loved them and spent time with them because both didnt have to work 10 hour shifts to get by in the world and own a nicer house and car to kep up with the Jones.

A whopper of a head appears the minute you pour this one.  And its blue!  Tragically, the taste isnt as original, lacking almost entirely in blueberry flavor (OK, maybe theres some there, but its very subtle - see Weyerbachers Raspberry Stout if you really want a fruit-flavored stout).  Theres an inexplicable harshness to this brew that the 4.5% alcohol doesnt account for.
Strong blueberry aroma and taste. Nice stuff.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2003 This is much more of a stout than a fruit beer. The fruit aromas and flavors meld well with the natural esters of the malt and are complemented well by the heavy roastiness. There are big hops in here as well and the bitterness of the roast dovetails nicely with the extending herbal bitterness. I appreciate the full stout flavor -- roasty, chewy and full bodied -- while the fruit and bitter extend the beer beyond the call of duty. Thanks PsychProf!

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 Pours with a good sized brown head that quickly settles on the black body. Huge blueberry/flowery aroma, big blueberry taste with a light ending.  Incredibly smooth tasting.  A unique stout that I hope to try again.  Thanks PsychProf!

The two Dark Horse brews I had last night were huge in flavour.  I mean, absolutely gigantic, heading-full-steam-towards-the-iceberg big.  Theres enough grace in the Wit to avoid crashing, but Im not so pleased with this one.  Maybe I just dont like fruit in my stouts, as I learned with Bells Cherry.  As with that beer, the fruit is well done - not cloying or plastic, but a definite, firm,  presence.  But again I find myself thinking - why do this to a decent roasty stout?  Its a good beer and Ill undertstand if future raves rocket it into cult status on RateBeer - I even admire the spirit of innovation that created it -  but its not my cup of, um, beer.

Extremely thick, chewy maltiness.  Lots of dark roasted malts, maybe a little too much.  Blueberry quality is extremely restrained, it is much more prevalent in the aroma than in the flavor.  Slight extract flavor, perhaps theyre using blueberry syrup?  But overall, pretty interesting beer.  Mine seemed more like PsychProfs first bottle than his rerate, subdued blueberry quality.  Thanks PsychProf!

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2003 Re-Rerate: On tap at Dark Horse in Marshall, MI. The palate of this one on tap is delectable. Thin head stays a long time, and then you are looking at a smooth, strong, hefty mirrored black surface. Perfect melding of flavors...more blueberry and it would get horrifying, more stoutish and it would barely be a fruit beer. Upping this one .2. Rerate: Not for the faint of heart or blueberry haters. Everything is over the top here, blueberry aroma and taste, dark dark dark roasted malt. And I mean dark. The head is dark brown, yet the body is lighter, alive. Still the same 3.7 rating, but I had to let it be known that this thing is challenging.
Original: 4/24/02: This one works for me...far lighter in the mouth than I expected. Nice aroma, not over the top. Taste components are a slight roastiness, and, of course, blueberry.
